blockquote.p: A phonetic alphabet contains combinations of letters, numbers, and characters which are known as "phones". A phone represents a discrete sound in a spoken language. Phones are used to create phonetic spellings that determine how a word should be pronounced to be recognized or spoken. System.Speech supports three phonetic alphabets:.
These elements contain the following attributes:

dl.dd: A system of phonetic notation based in part on the Latin alphabet, devised as a standardized representation of the sounds of spoken language. You can use this phonetic alphabet to specify pronunciations for any language.

A machine-readable phonetic alphabet, created by Microsoft, which is based on the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA). You can use this phonetic alphabet to specify pronunciations for any language except those that use the SAPI phonetic alphabet, see the next item.

The pronunciation alphabet used in System.Speech for the following languages:
Language-Culture Code Language Name Language ID
zh-TW Chinese (Taiwan) 404
zh-CN Chinese (PRC) 804
en-US English (United States) 409
fr-FR French (Standard) 40c
de-DE German (Standard) 407
jp-JP Japanese 411
es-ES Spanish (Spain, Traditional Sort) 40a

blockquote.p: This is a listing and cross reference of the consonant phones that are used by the three phonetic alphabets that System.Speech supports. See Phonetic Alphabet Reference.

Consonant symbols are one, two, or three characters in length. Single character labels are used for highly frequent, language-universal consonants. In general the first character signifies place plus voicing, and the second signifies manner. Labeling conventions carry across phonetic classes in the following ways:
Conventions for place of articulation and voicing labeling:

ul.li: Dentals and alveloars use D for voiced and T for voiceless
Alveolars use N for nasal and R for approximant
Labiodentals use V for voiced and F for voiceless
Velars use G for voiced and K for voiceless, NG for nasal
Bilabials use B for voiced and P for voiceless stops, M for nasal
Palatals use X for voiceless and Y for voiced

blockquote.p: Conventions for manner of articulation labeling:

ul.li: Single-character labels have manner encapsulated in choice of symbol: for example, M is nasal
Trills double up the first symbol

blockquote.p: These elements contain the following attributes:

dl.dd: The phone label specified in Microsoft’s Universal Phone Set (UPS).
The phone label specified in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) phone set.
The Unicode value from the IPA phone set.
The Speech API (SAPI) phone ID, which in most cases is the Unicode value.

This column describes the features of the phone, such as place of articulation, manner of articulation, phonation type, and airstream mechanism. See the Glossary of Phonetic Terms for more information about the features of phones.
The equivalent phone in ipaASCII phone set for reference.
The equivalent phone in X-SAMPA for reference.
A word that uses the phone and illustrates its sound.
The language of the example word.

blockquote.p: This is a listing and cross reference of the uncommon phones that are not listed in the other phone tables, but are used by the three phonetic alphabets that System.Speech supports. See Phonetic Alphabet Reference.
These elements contain the following attributes:

dl.dd: The phone label specified in Microsoft’s Universal Phone Set (UPS).
The phone label specified in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) phone set.
The Unicode value from the IPA phone set.
The Speech API (SAPI) phone ID, which in most cases is the Unicode value.
This column describes the features of the phone, such as place of articulation, manner of articulation, phonation type, and airstream mechanism. See the Glossary of Phonetic Terms
The equivalent phone in ipaASCII phone set for reference.
The equivalent phone in X-SAMPA for reference.
